results.title: Serving suggestion
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Kate Riedl and Tony Thorne
results.brief_description: A snot nosed kid called Kevin eats his way through the snack aisle in the supermarket. When Kevin decides to go for the ‘Chocky Pops’, he doesn’t realise that he’ll end up with more than a mouthful. The supermarket becomes a jungle in this impressive computer animated short.

results.title: Pleasure domes
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Maggie Fooke
results.brief_description: Is Cannes really like St. Kilda, or is it just a state of mind? Animated watercolour drawings and hand coloured photocopies shape this introspective reflection on the nature of landscape and human responses to it. It hints that our perception of landscape is never direct but always filtered through a set of constructs, either physical or psychological.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Maggie Fooke

results.title: Plastic
results.brief_description: Evan’s world is a dark one. It is only his imagination that affords him some escape. The outside world’s harshness leads him finally to subversion and his escape is complete. An excellent discussion starter for exploring the issues of difference, and society’s perceptions of disability.

results.title: Lovely day
results.brief_description: Lovely Day is a masterpiece of painterly animation art. Painstakingly rendered in the style of Hieronymus Bosch, the central character and accompanying putto-like figures evoke memories of a time when the pianola was the price of the parlour and partying involved an old fashioned knees up sing along.

results.title: Superpermanence
results.brief_description: superpermanence contains images that are magnifications of small sections of original frames, and plays with duplication, superimposition and colour manipulation.
results.description: superpermanence contains images that are magnifications of small sections of original frames, and plays with duplication, superimposition and colour manipulation.

results.title: Platform 1
results.brief_description: As a visitor descends the stairway into the Screen Gallery, her path will leave a trace through which imagery will emerge from the past — people ascending from a train platform in Australia one hundred years ago. The artwork is a live interplay between the present and the past. As ACMI visitors descend the stairs to encounter the future of screen arts, they pass through the lingering and ever-present influence of cinematic history. A wondrous, benign space of haunting, the staircase initiates Screen Gallery visitors into the ever-present power of cinematic history.

results.title: Gather
results.brief_description: A restrained, observational study of the groupings, gestures, and postures of people who gather to form temporary communities in the city. People are observed gathering for entertainment, for commemoration, for debate and contestation, for celebration. The city is seen as a shifting flux and flex of momentary comminglings.

results.title: Orka
results.brief_description: The images in “Orka” - which means “life force” - were shot by Steina in the wilds of her native Iceland in 1996. A “tracer” device records the micro-movements of nature over time, such as the paths of birds and waves. Steina’s digitally altered images of nature have a stark and often startling beauty.
